title: bella thorne advice wise women whoopi goldberg
story: Whoopi pointed out, quite reasonably in my view, that the young actress should not have those sorts of images on her phone in the first place. She said everyone knows such photos can be hi- jacked and used to threaten and embarrass.I am sure that Whoopi meant well but it all backfired when an emotional Bella posted a video saying how upset she was at being “shamed” by the presenter and actress, — calling her actions “sick and disgusting”.I find it utterly baffling that Bella was more distressed by the words of a middle-aged woman who had her best interests at heart than the saddo who tried to embarrass her by releasing nude photos on to the internet for all the world to see.It’s a great shame this has now escalated into a row between the two women, because I truly admire Bella for how she has handled the whole potential blackmailing situation.It was a masterstroke and instantly took all the power away from the snivelling little git who was hassling her. Bella was not ashamed or embarrassed by the intimate pictures and would not be held to ransom. Good for her.But surely it was far more upsetting to be the victim of a potential crime than receiving a slight scolding from Whoopi for being naive enough to take and keep those sorts of images in the first place.Bella had a right old rant on Instagram and has vowed never again to appear on The View — a chat show co-hosted by Whoopi which is the US version of our Loose Women.I feel very sorry for Bella because she was clearly extremely upset by what Whoopi had to say but I think her anger is misplaced.Whoopi was makIng a really important point, which affects everyone, not only those in the public eye.She was speaking for worried parents of teenagers and twentysomethings everywhere who are concerned that online photos of their children getting drunk, posing nude or even having sex will come back to haunt them.It is one of the real dangers of social media that our accounts are not really secure. they can be hacked with relative ease, falling out of “the cloud” and on to your boss’s Facebook — or, even worse, getting viewed by your mum and dad.There are people who think it is a jolly wheeze to post explicit photographs of former lovers online, or who do it as “revenge” for being dumped.Of course, there are those who have no common sense and post pictures of themselves romping in hotel rooms with girlfriends or boyfriends or boozily feeling each other up on holiday.The authorities are now cracking down. Last August, a man who hacked into hundreds of iCloud accounts of Hollywood actresses and leaked their nude pictures was sentenced to eight months in prison.George Garofano stole private photographs from movie stars including actresses Jenner Lawrence and Kirsten Dunst. It was horribly distressing for these women and I completely sympathise.However, the ease with which that slimy toad was able to access personal images proves thatyou don’t want to have potentially embarrassing photos put out there, then don’t take them in the first place — or just press the delete button.Maybe even go back to the Dark Ages, invest in a Polaroid camera and keep your naughty pictures under lock and key. The hackers are vile, but let us not give them the ammunition. And take heed of the advice from wise women such as Whoopi.I SINCERELY hope the latest rumours from the troubled set of the new Bond film prove to be without foundation.It’s being claimed that the film’s director, Cary Fukunaga, held up cast and crew during a complicated shoot because he was playing video games on his PlayStation.Apparently the production crew and actors were not amused at having to hang about for three hours because Cary wanted to play with his toys. I don’t blame them.I cannot believe someone would be so inconsiderate to fellow professionals.I was, however, more aghast at finding out Cary isn’t a spotty teenage geek, but a -year-old man.Surely he should have outgrown PlayStation by now – especially when he is already in charge of the world’s best video game, involving Aston Martin car chases, shootouts, beautul women and dastardly villains.WILLIAM and Kate showed how royals should react when their lestyle causes harm to a member of the public.Widow Irene Mayor, , was hit by a police motorbike escorting the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge to Windsor Castle. She is in hospital with serious injuries.As soon as Wills and Kate found out, they sent flowers and a hand-written note and have told Irene’s family they want to visit her whenever she is ready.I HAVE never watched Love Island. So it’s odd to see images and videos of strange, orange people with impossibly white teeth, like Molly-Mae Hague on my online news feeds and splashed across magazines when I haven’t a blinking clue who they are.And it is utterly bizarre that they all look and sound exactly alike.To be honest,I really need to see fit youngsters strutting around, uttering meaningless sounds and having sex, I will tune into a David Attenborough documentary.THE Fab Five presenters on makeover show Queer Eye are making the world a better place – one scruffy, messed-up person at a time.Makeovers are hardly a new concept but this series does much more than give someone a new outfit and haircut.The hosts lovebomb shy misfits who ask for help, as well as big-hearted people who just neglect themselves – then change their lives for ever.It’s a show full of heart and soul and I blub during every episode.This week I met the British star of Queer Eye, delightful Tan France, from Doncaster. He had a hard time growing up in a world where he had no role models and he feels a huge responsibility to young gay Asian men such as himself.Tan and the Queer Eye boys feature in the video for Taylor Swt’s new single, You Need To Calm Down, with some of my favourite people including RuPaul and Ryan Reynolds.The song hits you over the head a bit with its inclusivity – no bad thing – but the Queer Eye boys do it better just by being themselves.I HAD to look twice at this gorgeous selfie posted by This Morning’s Alison Hammond.She’s glowing with confidence and happiness.After becoming the spokeswoman for a slimming club Alison has lost so much weight and looks stunning.She has talked about being “embarrassed” by weighing st. But I’m so glad she lost weight gradually with a healthy eating plan and doing exercise she loves.I wish Alison all the best with her battle towards being happier, healthier and fitter and I know she will have helped other women with their weight issues too.I BLOODY love Matt Lucas. The Little Britain star saw on Twitter that Amy Dunn was being bullied because she had lost her hair and was being derided as a “Matt Lucas lookalike”.The comedian immediately sent the -year-old a message of support telling her she was beautul and how flattered he was to be compared to her.Amy, who suffers from alopecia, has had people laughing and pointing at her in the street because she happens to have a condition that means she is bald.I hope having Matt on her side has cheered Amy up and given her the confidence to ignore the morons who hurled abuse, and maybe even feel sorry for them for being such ar**holes.Matt is right. Amy is beautul, and so is he.I’M very much liking the look of Beecham House, the new ITV drama set in th Century India that airs tomorrow night.The trails look sumptuous and now Poldark’s Aidan Turner has gone all grungy, leading man Tom Bateman is a most welcome piece of eye candy.Beecham House is on ITV tomorrow at pm.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cabinet must stop theresa mays legacy plan
story: Some of her closest allies will not survive her departure. That is no reason now to help her force through a reckless spending spree which will hobble her successor post-Brexit.The Treasury has built up that “war chest” to handle the uncertainties of our future as a newly independent nation.It is not there to be plundered to make up for Mrs May’s failures since .Chancellor Philip Hammond is fighting to stop it.All his colleagues, but especially those with good prospects under a new leader, must back him.The Tories have a glimmer of a brighter future after three dismal years.It will be a disgraceoutgoing ministers sabotage it trying to rewrite the past.TORY minister Mark Field has rightly been suspended and apologised over his manhandling of a female eco protester.His force was excessive, even allowing for how little time he had to think as she strode towards the Chancellor’s table.But he cannot face criticism alone.The security was woeful. How could so many protesters stroll in, scream slogans and refuse to leave  No one was armed, but how could anyone be sure of that And why are authorities letting climate protesters believe they have a ine right to trespass  Or block major roads  Or wreck family holidays They now think that their hysterical claim to be “saving our planet from burning” trumps anyone ’s rights — a conviction fuelled by police feebly ­letting them paralyse London in April.Yet we are the first country to commit to net-zero emissions by . This year, the first time since the Industrial Revolution, more UK power will be produced from zero-carbon sources than fossil fuels.It’s time the sanctimonious outrage was directed somewhere it’s actually justied.THE latest drama surrounding Boris Johnson is troubling but madness has set in on the Left in its ­desperation to trash him.Every utterance over  years is being forensically examined for offences against “social justice” snowflakery.One half-witted Corbynite caricature, Laura ­Pidcock — an MP so keen to heal ision that she boasts of “viscerally” detesting all Tories — reckons Boris is “fuelled by homophobia and racism”.Which will be news to cosmopolitan, liberal-left London which twice elected him Mayor.But consider the stomach-churning hypocrisy of Labour’s hard left accusing a social liberal like Boris of being motivated by bigotry . . .When their own repugnant and blatant loathing of Jews has an entire community living in fear of a Corbyn Government.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: social mobility toff at top no10
story: Not that Old Etonians always make good Prime Ministers.The last one was David Cameron, and lookwhat a national catastrophe he turned out to be.For anyone who cares about social mobility, the depressing news is that  Downing Street is reserved for toffs. Boris will only be our th Prime Minister since the very first, Robert Walpole, who was in office from  to .The fact that more than a third of them went to Eton , suggests that social mobility in this country is in terminal decline.Indeed, when it comes to the children of ordinary homes reaching the highest office in the land, social mobility is stone-cold dead.Fee-paying privilege provides the fast-track to power. Yet it wasn’t always this way.There was a golden age of ­meritocracy in the last century when it was normal for our PMs to be educated by the state.Eton was still a bastion of academic excellence in those happy years. So was Harrow, which has produced seven Prime Ministers, and Westminster, which educated six.But between  and , there was enough healthy social mobility in this country for Harold Wilson, Ted Heath, Jim Callaghan, Margaret Thatcher and John Major — all educated at state schools — to become Prime Minister.Major and Callaghan didn’t even go to university. Callaghan couldn’t afford it, while Major left school at  with three O-levels.All five came from modest ­backgrounds, although Wilson, Heath and Thatcher were clever enough to get into Oxford University.For more than three decades, state-educated politicians competed with those who were the product of expensive private educations — and beat them to the top job.This is not an argument against Boris Johnson becoming Prime ­Minister simply because he went to Eton. Boris seems like the man most likely to prevent a Marxist government. This would destroy our economy — a fate far worse than either staying in or leaving the European Union.SoI was a Tory MP or party member, then I would probably prefer Boris to take on Brussels, Corbyn and the Brexit Party.But yet another old Etonian in  Downing Street proves that social mobility is nowhere near what it was in the last century. Andwe care about a fair and equal society, then that should concern us all.It feels signicant that the first candidate to be eliminated from the Tory leadership race was Esther McVey — the candidate from  the least privileged background, reinforcing the belief that Westminster is a closed shop.But when it comes to getting on in le, and even getting to Downing Street, it should not matter a damn where you were born.Your ability — and your willingness to graft — should matter far more than Mummy and Daddy’s bank ­balance.Le can never be totally fair. But two Old Etonian PMs in less than ten years is grotesque.  If there is to be a bright, shining future for this country after we leave the EU, there MUST be more social mobility.Once he has sorted out Brexit  and buried Corbyn, perhaps our Old ­Etonian PM will do something about it. Because inequality is still entrenched at birth.And that stinks.WHAT is mankind’s greatest invention  The Internet  The printing press  The steam engine  Penicillin If, like me, you are allergic to penicillin, then the gold shorts that Kylie Minogue wore in her Spinning Around promo probably have the edge on all of them. Kylie’s gold gear might make a comeback when she plays Glastonbury next Sunday.And  years after their debut, nobody has ever developed an allergy to them.As the wolf evolved into the dog, it sussed that making its eyes bigger made the humans go all soft and gooey inside.Dr Juliane Kaminski, of the University of Ports- mouth, says: “The evidence is compelling that dogs developed a muscle to raise the inner eyebrow after they were domesticated from wolves. It seems to elicit a strong desire in humans to look after them.”Those puppy-dog eyes are designed to make your heart melt.Certainly when Stan, our Cavalier King Charles spaniel, looks at me with his enormous, big round peepers, I understand the three little words he is trying to say.Give. Stan. Cheese.IT is weird the way even the greatest TV series can go off the boil.On the surface, the second series of Killing Eve has everything that made the first such a blast.Jodie Comer is still brilliant as psychopathic assassin Villanelle, doing a iety of convincing accents and changing her clothes more often than Diana Ross in concert.Sandra Oh is again wonderful as the sexually confused, domestically challenged spook.But I have watched the entire second series now and it just doesn’t catch fire the way the first did.And that is because the first series of Killing Eve had three female stars in Jodie Comer, Sandra Oh and – behind the scenes – Fleabag creator Phoebe Waller-Bridge, who wrote the script.Now Waller-Bridge has gone off to save the screenplay of the next James Bond movie.And Killing Eve badly misses her magic dust.JEW-HATING has become the racism  that is permissible.The Prime Minister of Malaysia, Mahathir Mohamad, told the Cambridge Union debating society that his Jewish friends: “Are not like the other Jews – that’s why they are my friends.”He got a laugh.If he had said “black” or “Muslim”, he would have been nicked.THERE are some scary TV shows out there.Doing Question Time is daunting because you can be certain that at least half of the audience will hate your guts.Have I Got News For You  is forbidding because the ageing team captains and presenters have been doing it since the dawn of time and are used to the show’s format .But nothing comes close to the terror factor of Mastermind.To sit in that black leather chair as the lights go down is to know true stage fright. So Hamish Cameron must have been a very brave man indeed.Hamish held the record for the most appearances on Mastermind –  – and after filming the final last November, he learned he had terminal cancer.Shortly before the final was broadcast last week, Hamish died at the age of .The BBC had considered postponing the broadcast as a mark of respect but Hamish had instructed his family that he wanted the show to go on.As someone who vowed “never again” after sitting in that hot seat just the once, I can only salute Hamish’s courage.The Mastermind catchphrase “I’ve started so I’ll finish” could have been invented for this fearless man.IF Heathrow gets a third runway, then the impact on the environment will be huge, with hundreds of extra flights landing and taking  off every day.And that’s just for Emma Thompson!Their honeymoon must have been filthy.ANDREA LEADSOM says she was told by senior Tory women that they could not back her because the party couldn’t have “another woman” Prime Minister so soon after Theresa May.But the Tories’ past willingness to be led by a woman is surely something to celebrate.  The Conservatives will almost certainly be on their third female Prime Minister before the -year-old male-dominated Labour Party has its first.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: love island 2019 insecurities
story: It is a phenomenon and has the nation gripped. So why feel guilty about watching it The appeal of this show is fairly obvious — it’s the intimate access you get.Viewers feel like they’re on holiday on on the island too, as invisible guests.The ultimate fly-on-the-wall experience.We hear the most private of conversations, witness the most explosive fallouts. We even get in the shower with them.It’s so intimate that it feels the same as when you read someone ’s diary.Of course, we are watching insanely beautul people parading around in tiny scraps of swimwear. But no matter how gorgeous the contestants, each one is revealed to be as fragile as the next.I think that is where our real fascination lies.Surely they should all be full of confidence, looking the way they do  And yet they seem to be just as insecure as the rest of us.I like the fact that the show is a portal into a generation to which I no longer belong.I’ve learned so much about how young men and women behave and, until Maura uttered the words, I didn’t even know it was possible to have “fanny flutters”.Another thing I like is the escapism. Surely it’s no coincidence that Love Island is at peak popularity during a time when the news is totally dominated with gloom, doom — and Brexit.Personally, I’m also intrigued by the fake hair and nails — and the very y process of getting ready for a night out. I’m luckyI put a comb through my hair.The amount of make-up they manage to get on to their faces is astonishing — although the irony is that the one girl all the guys seem to like, Lucie, is a surfer chick who doesn’t wear make-up.There is also a real cruelty to the show, though. There is always someone better, someone more chosen. The voting process is brutal and leaves all of the contestants anxious about whether or not people like them.This show strips people of everything that is important, other than their body. They are measured on what they look like and little .As a result, lots of people have questioned the damage caused to the mental health of the contestants.There have been more than , complaints to Ofcom about this series already.But there are good things about Love Island.While it’s not exactly the kind of equality that women have been fighting for over the past  years, there’s no denying that female members in the house are as free as the men to proposition members of the opposite sex.In my day, all we had was: “My mate fancies you.” But Maura said of one guy that he gave her “fanny flutters”.When my daughter Sophia was asked to go on the show, she thought it would be fun to be on a free holiday. You can see her point.But no mother wants to watch their child on Love Island. We all know there are plenty of things our kids do that we don’t know about — and that’s the way it should stay.But it’s not just that. One reason I enjoy being part of the Apprentice is because it celebrates young people for their skills, ambition and what they achieve.They know they aren’t being valued for their looks — they are being valued for so much more than that.That said, no one’s self- esteem should be based on how others value us.I’ve often thought that my biggest superpower is that I really don’t care what people think about me.When I’m on the beach I’m not bothered about which bits and pieces are jiggling.Why  Because there is so much more to me than what I look like in a bikini.Or, rather, as a footballer’s we once said to me: “All I’ve got is my looks — at least you’ve got your personality.”I know it was a back-handed compliment. But you know what, I’m fine with that.LOTTIE Moss said on social media that she feels “uncomfortable” with her weight at the moment – as she posted a picture of herself in a dress on a night out.My first thought was she’s going to look back at those photos when she is in her fties and wonder how she could have felt uncomfortable when she looked like this.My second was she can’t worry that much because the dress she’s wearing is almost completely see-through.BOSSES of the Isle of Wight Festival have been criticised by two mental-health charities for banning Jess Glynne for le after the singer cancelled her show at the last minute, owing to anxiety.Anxiety is a debilitating condition which blights the lives of many people.I’m sorry to hear that Jess is one of those people.But when she knows she suffers from this condition, her choice to stay out partying with the Spice Girls until am on the day she was due to perform seems, well, questionable.Having been out drinking all night before work is enough to make even the most level-headed person anxious.To then go on social media advertising that fact, before effectively phoning in sick to work, is also a tad foolish.By doing that, Glynne gave the impression she chose partying over a commitment – and that is not a good look.If we have one job to do as parents, it is to teach our kids the importance of doing the things that need to be done, when they need to be done, whether you like it or not.When I see a young person doing what they said they would do, despite challenges, I know they’ve got backbone.It’s called resilience, grit, determination, and it’s about being irrepressible. Those are some of the most admirable traits a person can have.Anxiety is awful but it’s certainly not helped by partying until the early hours of a work day.THIS week there has been good and bad news for Boris Johnson. The good news is that it looks ashe is going to be our next Prime Minister.The bad news is not that early-hours row with his partner – it’s his new haircut.He used to have “The Trump”, a sort of comb-forward that hid his balding. But his barber has cut it off and, instead of the long-haired blond bombshell look, he’s now a blond basin with thinning top.Boris, please take it from me, when you go into a hairdresser’s the first thing you do is check out the hairstyle of the person holding the scissors.Anyway, I guess it grows back – and soon will be the haystack it’s always been. Now all Boris needs is a new suit.OOPS! My heart goes out to the mum of the rampaging toddler at a Swiss art show who knocked over a sculpture of a fly worth £,.My main question, though, is how a plastic sculpture of a fly could be worth so much money Someone, somewhere, is having a laugh. Right I WAS trying to work out what was unusual about the recent photo of actor Rob Lowe on the red carpet.I realised it’s this. He is a handsome, successful star who is still with his we – Sheryl Berkoff – after  years without trading her in for a younger model.And they look happy.A rare sight in Hollywood, so good luck to both of them.TO be fair, Sofia Richie pretty much pulled it off when she sported the latest bicycle shorts onesie – the trend you prayed would never happen.But all I can say is, I’m glad I don’t follow fashion.WHAT’S in a word  You might think nothing much. And it’s a small thing in a way, but Sainsbury’s needs to be called out for assuming on its hair-removal product that all doctors are male.Its instructions say: “Consult your usual doctor and show him the packaging.”No doubt lots of people will respond by saying that us women are far too easily offended.But it is assumptions such as this behind the fact that, for every £ a man makes, a woman only makes p.We have to stamp out this unconscious bias by calling it out every time we see it.AMAZING that it’s  years since Friends hit our TVs.But judging by pictures of its stars Jenner Aniston, , and Courteney Cox, , on vacation in their bikinis, they still look fantastic.Even more amazing is that they are genuine friends.It just goes to show thatyou eat well, work out and look after yourself, you don’t have to be fat and flabby at .*Note to self – eat better and go to the gym. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The Foreign Secretary said his rival was being a coward and running scared of proper scrutiny of his Brexit plans.Today it was revealed that Sky would cancel their debate for a one-on-one clash between the pair tomorrowBoris continued to decline to take part.Mr Hunt demanded Boris step up and face the music days after police were called to the home he was sharing with girlfriend Carrie Symonds following reports of a blazing row.He told Sky News today: Its very disrespectful to Conservative party members to avoid all media scrutiny and head-to-head debates.You cant become PM without answering dferent questions youre going to have answer on day one.Sometimes in politics you can fudge, but on Brexit you cant.The new prime minister will have a new mandate and spell out exactly what they want to do.But he refused to comment further on the remarks about his private le, saying only it was a matter for him.A spokesman for Mr Hunts campaign added today: Trying to duck debates and run down the clock until after postal ballots have been ed is just cynical and complacent. title: travellers exeter chiefs car park demand money leave
story: Around half a dozen cars, vans and caravans have turned up at the park and ride in Sowton, Devon, today after they initially set up camp in the car park of the Exeter Chiefs rugby ground.The Online: Four caravans are currently parked at Sowton Park and Ride.The site remains open to the public and bus services are running as normal.We will be seeking an order from the court in due course refused though and managed to evict them within less than  hours of them arriving, after obtaining a high court enforcement order from a company in the Midlands.Security staff have remained at the title: britains cheapest street gangs poo
story: Peering through a crack in the curtain, she watches in disgust as a local woman pulls down her pants, squats, and poos on the pavement outside her Liverpool home.The bizarre sight would be enough for most of us to call the police, but for Mel, , and her family its become the norm.They moved onto the Webster Triangle in Wavertree, Liverpool,  months ago when she and partner Rob, , nabbed a £ house on the UK’s cheapest street.The childhood sweethearts - who feature on Channel ’s £ Houses: Britain’s Cheapest Street tonight - bought the house though a council scheme to sell off empty houses for a quid, which was set up to bring , empty properties back into use.Families can apply to the council to buy the properties, and,successful, they are allocated a house on the condition they stay there for five years.Despite receiving , applications, progress has been slow and a council spokesman says only  families have been moved into the houses, which all come without plumbing or electricity.As a result, the empty houses have been targeted by arsonists and gangs, who linger in the streets causing trouble, making le hell for the few families that have moved in.On Mel and Robs street, only three out of  houses are occupied.Many were due for demolition to make way for new social housing - but plans were scrapped when the coalition government closed the Housing Renewal Fund in .At night, the rundown area becomes a magnet for gangs, drug dealers and arsonists. Last year, they even found a bullet on their doorstep after a mass shooting nearby.Another resident found  bags of cannabis with a street value of £, dumped in a skip.Despite loving her home, Mel admits shes too scared to go outside at night.She says: “It’s quite intimidatingyou’re a woman on your own and you walk out in the dark and you’ve got big groups of teenagers hanging outside. I just stay inside.”Police in Wavertree recorded  crimes in April alone - with anti-social behaviour and violence topping the list.The show’s cameras caught large groups of youths outside the house on Mischief night, drinking, shouting and wheeling each other up and down the street in stolen supermarket trollies.The couple hear fights outside their front door and they live in fear of stones and bricks coming through their window.“There are a lot of bricks lying around - and the fact that we have made such an effort on our house is asking for trouble,” says Mel.“When we got this house we wanted to do it because we wanted an easy le and we didn’t want to be worrying about mortgages... but I didn’t want to be worrying about my windows getting smashed either.“I don’t want to leave my house and be panicking that my house is getting ransacked.”Marauding teenagers aren’t the only unwelcome visitors to the street, either.“In the past we’ve had problems with a woman who was using the street as a toilet - and I saw her again last night,” says Mel.“She got quite aggressive with me and physically got hold of me, and I thought: ‘What have I got myself into here ’“This is not what I want to be doing: sitting down eating my dinner and someone pulls their pants down... and we can see them out of the window.”Inside their four walls, Mel and Rob’s home is beautul, with clean bright rooms, a spacious kitchen, cosy living room and modern tiled bathroom.“It’s definitely our dream home,” says Mel. “We don’t have a social le but we don’t feel we’re missing it because we love being here.“It’s so special because we did it all ourselves so it makes us proud.”But outside their door, lies a “ghost street”, lined with derelict houses boarded up with metal shutters.“I feel like we’ve been forgotten about,” says Mel. “I come out of my front door and my view is unoccupied houses and they’re falling into more and more disrepair. The house opposite has big cracks in it. It could go any moment.”Community worker Debbie and her partner Steve, who also feature in the programme, have big plans for their double fronted £ property at the top of the Triangle.Debbie, who had been renting for  years and was refused a mortgage because of past health problems, dreams of a walk in wardrobe, off-road parking and a ft kitchen with quartz worktops and central island.Carpet cleaner Steve, wants a wide screen TV, Play Station  and a chaise longue so he can put his feet up.Their renovations would cost £, but Steve thinks they can keep it under £, as he does most of the work himself.But he admits the area is not ideal and the house has already been targeted by vandals who have snapped a drainpipe climbing over his fence.“I’m putting my blood and guts into this for her so she can have somewhere nice to live, although the area is not up to much,” he says. “It’s a bit rough.“All my brothers and sisters say you’re mad, going round there. I’m a bit dubious but you’ve got to give it a go for a £. Beggars can’t be choosers.”Arson is also a problem and Steve was recently worried when fire engines were called to put out a fire in one of the empty houses over the road.Local newsagent Sam says ‘several’ of the houses have been set ablaze by local yobs.“They’re targeting the empty houses,” says Steve. “The problem I have is that the house next door to me is empty as well. “You can’t be here  hours  a day stopping it.”£ Houses: Britain’s Cheapest Street airs on Channel  tonight at .pmOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: alan barnes moving fifth house mugging
story: The frail -year-old, who broke his collar bone in the shocking  assault, has been in his plush three-bedroom new-build since November .But he has said he wants to sell the house and move into a bungalow instead.He bought the detached property, which overlooks Saltwell Park in Gateshead, for £, but is now flogging it for £,.An online fund set up by single mum Katie Cutler raised £, to remove him from the house where he was shoved over by mugger Richard Gattis while putting out the bins.But Alan has never been able to settle and has moved house frequently over the years - making a loss with each sale.It is estimated he will have lost a total of £, of his donated money after his latest move - which will be his fth.He said: Moving is just part of who I am, I dont like how long I have to walk to the shops, especially when its raining. I dont like getting wet.I would like a bungalow but I havent found anything suitable yet. Ill just be staying here until I find something .This is a nice light house, but its quite quiet. You dont really see anyone.After launching the fund, Katie became embroiled in a bitter legal row over funds she owed PR Claire Barber,which Alan then offered to help pay off.He used the donations to buy a £, two-bedroom Victorian terrace, in his native Low Fell, but struggled to settle in.Then Alan moved a mile down the road to a semi-detached two-bedroom property, which cost £,, but put it up for sale just two months later.After a year on the market, Alan accepted an offer of just £, so he could sht again.Last year, the pensioner began renting a flat to be free of the ties of a house - but then decided to purchase the flash new-build through Miller homes.All of the properties Alan has lived in have been within the a one mile area of Gateshead - where he is sure he will find his dream bungalow.Alan, who has struggled with height and growth problems since birth and suffered a fall earlier this year, said: You just have to take what le chucks at you.“I have a plate in my leg now, but I dont mind, it doesnt hurt. Its cm by cm and has one screw, or so they told me.It bothers me more than what that lad did to me to be honest, but I forgave him a long time ago. Its the Christian thing to do.Ive always had a thing for houses, I like to pick and choose how the place looks. Im quite particular, like I dont like the tap in the kitchen. Its no good.Gattis was jailed for four years after admitting assault with intent to rob. It is understood that Gattis was released from prison earlier this year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cops ram moped mugger london
story: Dashcam footage shows a Scorpion Squad cop ploughing into the moped as he carries out tactical contact on a busy street in front of stunned pedestrians.The controversial manoeuvre was brought in last year after the country was gripped by a violent wave of moped muggers swiping phones, watches and bags.It was filmed for a Channel  documentary that captures the politan Polices special taskforce, Operation Venice, as they try to crackdown on the crime.Cops can be seen racing to catch the moped rider as he swerves through the streets of London.Seconds later, the driver attempts to move around a police car but he smashes into the bonnet and crashes to the ground.As he makes a daring bid for freedom, cops can be seen spraying him with a high tech water pistol, which marks moped thugs with invisible liquid that can later be used to link them to a crime.The forensically-tagged liquid called SelectaDNA clings on skin, clothes and vehicles for three months and glows under UV light.Several officers can then be seen forcing the suspect to the ground before he is arrested on suspicion of five offences, failing to stop for police, suspected theft of a motor vehicle, possession of a class a drug with intent to supply, failing a roadside drug test and dangerous driving.One officer tells Snatch and Grab: Moped Gangs on the Rampage: We have no desire to knock them off and cause any injury to them.However, that is a tactic that is available to us. If it is appropriate for us to use it, we will use it.Dramatic footage released last November showed Scotland Yard’s Scorpion pursuit teams hitting mopeds and sending suspects sprawling over car bonnets and flying across the tarmac.However, under existing laws, cops chasing moped thugs are subject to the same legal test for careless and dangerous driving offences as members of the public.Eventhey escape prosecution, cops can be investigated for gross misconduct and sacked.Cops who face charges often have to wait years before having their names cleared.The Home Office has insisted it is “reviewing” the law to give officers greater protection but critics said they must push through new legislation as a priorityThe documentary also interviews members of moped gangs who commit crimes and vigilantes who risk their lives to hunt the yobs.Scotland Yard introduced the bold new tactic of ramming moped thieves to widespread acclaim after violent gangs wreaked havoc on the streets of Lawless London in a terrying crime epidemic.The growth of moped crime - in which some criminals have stolen up to  phones in an hour - has exploded by , per cent across the UK in the past three years.And Lawless London has seen the highest spike in moped muggings, where over , separate offences were recorded last year alone.Victims are often targeted as theyre coming out of tube stations and other transport hubs where theyre more vulnerable to attacks.Thieves snatch handbags, watches and other expensive items before making an easy getaway.Cops had been criticised due to a widespread belief that they werent allowed to pursue a suspect on a mopedthey werent wearing a helmet.But proposed changes in the law make it explicit that specially trained police drivers can chase a rider without a helmet.Forces have previously unveiled other tactics to fight moped crime, like automatic tyre deflation devices and DNA tagging spray.And the tactics appear to be working - while there were , offences of moped crime in London between January and October last year, the same period has seen , offences this year - a reduction of  per cent.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: unknown side effects hay fever treatments
story: But while you may think these products are helping ease the symptoms, what many people dont know is that they can come with some very surprising side effects.So,youve started suffering from a sore throat or your nostrils feel irritated, it might not be down to your pollen allergy.And with pollen levels set to peak this week, its probably worth knowing what side-effects could cause you misery.Allergy expert Dr Daniel Fenton, from London Doctors Clinic, said there are five common symptoms to look out for...The tablets you will see on the shelves include Loratidine , Cetirizine , Chlorpheniramineand Diphenhydramine .They are very effective at providing an all-day benefit against pollen.The first two on the list are fairly long-acting, non-drowsy antihistamines, but The latter two are drowsy antihistamines.Some people avoid these due to their sedative effects, but should perhaps think twice.They are very effective and quick acting, but last for shorter periods of time, meaning you may need them - times a day.As a perennial hay fever sufferer, I utilise a non-sedative antihistamine during the day, and a sedative one at night time to help me sleep through the summer nights, with the window ajar and without sneezing all night.If these fail to help, it is worth speaking with your GP. Fexofenadineis a fantastic antihistamine that is only available on prescription. In my experience is one of the most effective around.And whilst some antihistamines are marketed as non-drowsy, some iniduals are particularly sensitive, and will still find themselves experiencing some fatigue.Some lesser known side effects include a dry mouth throat, dry eyes and blurred vision.Medications that block histamine receptors help allergic conditions, but these types of medications can reduce mucous and aqueous production, which cause dry eye and mouth complaints.Adding eye drops to your regime can be really useful to help combat the itchy eyes.Nasal decongestants are often combined with anticholinergic medications which together contribute to dry eyes, dilated pupils and decreased response to bright light.The dilated pupils interfere with your ability to focus on objects and can, therefore, contribute to blurry vision.Boots pharmacist Natalie Masters said: “You may have seen reports on rising pollen counts this weekend.If you’re a hayfever sufferer, don’t panic. When there’s more pollen in the air, your symptoms may worsen, but there are lots of steps you can take to alleviate these.Prevention is key, which means avoiding coming into contact with pollen in the first place.Grassy areas are often best avoided andyou can, don’t spend time outdoors at the times when pollen counts are highest, typically the early morning and late afternoon and evening.If you need to go outside, applying a petroleum jelly balm to the inside of your nostrils or using an allergy barrier nasal spray can help prevent pollen from entering your nostrils, whilst larger wraparound sunglasses can help stop pollen from irritating your eyes.There’s also several products you can purchase which can help to alleviate your symptoms when they start flaring up.Speak to your pharmacist about anti-histamine tablets, hayfever eye drops or a suitable steroid nasal spray.If you’ve been outdoors when the pollen count is high, make sure to shower and wash your hair once you get home to wash away any stray pollen particles.Regularly vacuuming and dusting your house with a damp cloth and washing and drying your clothes indoors may also help to keep your home a pollen-free zone.Importantly, try not to be worried or stressed about your hayfever. It has been claimed that hayfever can be exacerbated by this, so try to keep calm and consider dferent products and methods – hopefully you’ll soon find what works best for you.”Boots is currently has their own brand hay fever products on offer for  for £, including Boots One-A-Day Allergy Relief mg tabletsand  Boots Hayfever Relief for Adults  micrograms dose Nasal Spray  Metered Sprays .Branded products are also on offer at two for £.Nasal Sprays are particularly helpful for the rhinitisor blocked nose symptoms, which antihistamine tablets may not always take care of. Beconase is always a good start, but mometasoneor Fluticasone based sprays such as Avamys and Dymista, can provide that next step for relief.But in some iniduals, nasal sprays can cause some localised irritation within the nostrils, and even nose bleeds.The most important thing about nasal sprays is ensuring you are using them correctly. It is worth noting that they do not work immediately, and their effects are cumulative, meaning the longer you use them, the better the response – so you’ll need patience before you see results.Prolonged use of over the counter decongestant nasal sprays can create a rebound rhinosinusitisused for too long – in essence, they can make symptoms worseused for more than  or  days.What should you do should you experience any of these symptoms Dr Fenton says thatyou experience any of these side effects, its important to discuss them with your GP.He said: There is a multitude of alternative antihistamines, spray and drops that may be more suited to you.Alternatives include using medications used for asthma, such as Montelukast, which is excellent for the runny nose component of hay fever.In addition, some well-known antacidsdespite mainly being used for acid reflux and heartburn, can actually have great antihistamine effects.When all  fails, you may consider the hay fever injection, which is a steroid-based injection. This is not to be taken lightly, as is not without risks, but it can be beneficial to those with sever hay fever.Dr Fenton added: The truth behind hay fever treatment is that it can be trial and error.You have to take the time to find the right combination of treatments for you.Speaking to your GP is useful, as they will take you through all of the options and recommend, prescribe and administer the correct hay fever medications as needed.

title: sunny beach nightclub bulgaria holiday
story: Den Glade Viking is one of the many party bars at the Sunny Beach resort - a huge party town by the Black Sea where young Brits flock for the summer.In pictures taken at the bars many events and parties, ladies and gents can be seen frolicking together and dancing scantily-clad on top of the bar.Speaking to the Daily Star, a spokesperson for the raunchy club said that dancing naked on the bar was encouraged.He said: Anyone can dance naked on bars.Our slogan is the only place where it’s allowed to dance naked on the bar’.Events at Den Glade Viking include the UV party - where teens draw rude images on each other with brightly coloured pens.The bars spokesperson added: “There’s tonnes of mischievous sex games going on during the beach parties and Full Moon Parties.“Your typical - crowd games.”After her visit, Shannon Currie, from Wigan in Greater Manchester, left a positive review on the bars Facebook page and said its the only place that allows a naked dance on the bar.She added: I cant wait to be back.Other young Brits on Facebook have raved about the party bar too, calling it the best place to party in Sunny Beach and saying they had some of the best nights of their le there.The bar is part of a pub crawl run by workers at the resort.Den Glade Viking is one of a few stops that offer free drinks and shots to young people who come along for the party.The nightclub has a pool that is frequented by hardcore party-goers during the day.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
